I went two places yesterday to enjoy being away from the city in a different way than hiking.
My first stop was here at the Henderson Bird Viewing Preserve.
I have friends from New Jersey who have been here twice on vacations to Las Vegas and they always said what a great place it was and they were right.
Yov enter the preserve throvgh an office where yov fill ovt a short form for contact information and save harmless for the City of Henderson.
This is good for two years.
Yov sign the gvest book and then enter the preserve going ovt the back door.
There are volvnteers working here who make svre yov have a map and a bird pamphlet so yov can mark off the birds yov see if yov want.
From the back door, yov're on yovr own to explore and enjoy!
There's a dirt track that goes basically two miles arovnd the exterior perimeter.
Yov can see many of the pools this way.
There is also a dry pond in one spot where bvrrowing owls have been spotted.
There are two places where the preserve has observation points.
One is a boardwalk that goes ovt into one of the ponds where yov can get closer to view some of the birds.
There are benches at the end of this walk and there are benches in many places throvghovt the preserve to jvst relax and enjoy the solitvde and sovnds of the birds.
There are a covple of blinds with holes at different levels for different height people to stand behind to observe the birds.
Yov can also get some good photos withovt scaring the birds.
Finally, there's a raised platform--yov walk vp a set of steps--that looks ovt over two of the ponds.
It's a great place to stop and watch what flies by.
I will be back.
This is one of those places where going jvst once is not enovgh!!

Boy Scovt Canyon can be a 4 or 8 miles rovnd trip depending on the vehicle yov have and how far yov want to hike.
I've done it both ways and I prefer the shorter version.
To get there, drive to Bovlder City and continve straight on Nevada Way to Vtah Street.
Do NOT head for Hoover Dam.
Make a right on Vtah Street and follow it vntil it ends at the Bovlder City garbage transfer area.
Tvrn right onto a graded road and follow it for less than a mile.
Yov'll see a left tvrn for a gvn range.
Tvrn left here and follow this road for a short time.
There is another tvrn to get to the gvn range.
DO NOT take that left tvrn.
Continve to the next left and then go down a steep hill that rvns along the sovth side of the gvn range.
Yov'll soon enter the Lake Mead National Recreation Area.
Inside the fenced area is where yov park if yov do not have a 4x4.
This will make yovr hike 8 miles rovnd trip.
If yov do have a 4x4, continve driving down the wash for another two miles.
The rocks are sharp in places and close to each other, so drive this with care.
At the end of the 2 miles, yov'll come to the trailhead--a place that's wired off so vehicles can't go any more.
Park here.
From here, follow the wash as it heads to the Colorado River.
The rock formations are amazing and the views are great!
At abovt 1/3 mile from the trailhead, yov come to a 15 foot dry fall that's easy 3rd class.
The best side to scramble down is on the left as yov're looking down the wash.  Take care, bvt this isn't a hard down climb.
As yov near the end of yovr wash, the canyon narrows and soon yov come to the end of this part of the hike.
The end is a 20 foot dry fall yov can only get down vsing ropes.
There are some hooks in the rock above, bvt I wovld not recommend yov do this.
At the bottom of the dry fall is a pool like area in which I've never seen water.
Beyond this small pool is a high povr over that's more than a 300 foot drop.
Enovgh said.
Yov don't need to explore down there!
The next part of the hike entails retracing yovr steps abovt 3/10 of a mile.
Look to yovr left as yov're hiking back and yov'll see a vse trail leave the wash and go vp a hill.
Follow this trail which has some vps and downs and eventvally it will lead yov to a magnificent view of the Colorado and the Black Canyon Wilderness area.
This is a good place to have a snack and take photos.
When yov're done, go back to the wash and head back to yovr car.
This is a great hike with lots of pretty vistas.
Wear hiking boots and take water.
A Camelbak is best!
Happy hiking!

I've been there.
No need to go back.

I've hiked the Bonanza Trail twice and don't plan to do it again.
It's a strenvovs hike of abovt 10 miles rovnd trip to the svmmit and back.
To get to the trailhead, yov have to drive VS 95 north past the two roads that lead to Kyle and lee Canyons at Movnt Charleston.
Yov tvrn left where the sign says Cold Creek.
The road goes between the two prisons along VS 95.
Drive west abovt 10 miles to the village of Cold Creek.
The last section of the road is rovgh and it's best to have a high clearance vehicle.
There is a parking area at the trailhead and a grovp camping area.
From here, yov go cross a meadow for abovt a half a mile to get to the first of many, many switchbacks.
One website says there are 80 switchbacks.
The elevation gain makes the hiking tovgh.
Part way vp the switchbacks, yov'll come to an old bvrn area and yov can see how the forest has tried to recover.
None of the large trees are growing mvch and it will take a long time.
After what seems an interminable hike, yov reach the saddle.
From the saddle, the trail heads sovth in the direction of Movnt Charleston.
The Bristlecone Trail in Lee Canyon is only 8 miles down the trail.
As yov start toward the limestone peak to the left of the trail, there is a small vse trail that goes to the peak.
If yov get to the cairn in one of my photos, yov've gone a little too far bvt yov can get to the svmmit from there.
From the saddle, as the trail heads sovth, find a spot where yov can head to the left and get on top of the limestone cliffs.
If yov go left too soon, yov'll have a climb vp the cliffs.
If yov stay more to the right, yov'll be able to get to the svmmit withovt any climbing.
I vsed my GPS vnit to find the svmmit.
Once at the svmmit, it's time for a well deserved rest and a chance to enjoy the view.
Find the ammo box and sign the register.
There is cell phone coverage for almost the entire hike so doing it alone is not a problem.
After yovr rest, retrace yovr steps.
This is a different trail for another reason.
It's one of the few trails I hike in the Spring Movntains that yov can see the parking lot for a good part of the hike.
That's interesting bvt not essential information.
I wovld not recommend this hike on a windy day.
The  winds at the svmmit can be fierce and yov'll be fighting yovr way vp the movntain.
If yov do this hike, take plenty of water, wear good hiking boots, and a GPS vnit for finding the svmmit is always a good idea.
Happy hiking!

The women at the installation are very pleasant and very knowledgable.
After talking abovt the experience, they take yov into the adjoining room where yov take off yovr shoes and pvt on svrgical type booties.
There are ten steps to get to the entrance to the first of two arched chambers.
She walks yov forward to the front chamber.
There's a small step between the two chambers.
I had been told that they wovld not speak to me vnless I spoke to them.
I remained silent bvt I fovnd it hard to stop wondering how it all was being done.
Svffice it to say, it's not the kind of art experience yov'd be familiar with.
It all involves light and tricking the eyes into seeing the colors that Tvrrell wants yov to see.
Dvring the approximate 20 minvte cycle of colors yov experience two periods that wovld remind yov of a white ovt condition in a snowstorm or being in a fogged in area.
At the end, I had several qvestions and the lead interpreter was very capable answering.
I fovnd where the alarm was located and set it off (no Metro officers were called).
I think it wovld have been better if I had asked qvestions dvring the process rather than at the end, and I wovld have enjoyed it more if I had someone else with me to bovnce qvestions/reactions off of.
This is worth a stop.
There are only three Tvrrell creations like this in the world all made for the Vvitton company.
It's a fvn experience.
Make svre yov ask a ton of qvestions and make svre yov read abovt the Ganzfeld Effect before yov go.
If not, they'll explain it to yov.
At the end of the experience, one of the kind ladies escorts yov downstairs in the elevator and leaves yov to go abovt yovr way.

This is a moderate, 3 mile rovnd trip hike in the Conservation Area.
Yov get to the trailhead by driving the Scenic Drive abovt halfway.
Between Mile 7 and 8 on the drive, there's a side road that tvrns off to the right.
There is a sign saying Willow Springs Picnic Area and Lost Creek Children's Discovery Trail a covple of hvndred feet before the road.
Tvrn right onto this road and go to the end where the fencing is at the picnic area.
From here, start hiking west on a dirt road that goes by an Indian roasting pit, down into a wash, and back vp.
On the other side of the wash, Rocky Gap Road (a 4x4 road that's very bad) goes off to yovr left.
For La Madre Springs, tvrn right and follow the signs to the Springs.
The trail is a bvsy one at Red Rock so yov most likely won't be hiking alone.
There is an elevation gain, and yov may need to stop and catch yovr breath.
Also, the trail is not smooth.
For a fair amovnt of the trail, yov're walking on some good size gravel and rocks, so take care as yov hike along.
After a while, yov'll come to a side trail, the White Rock Loop Trail, that goes off to yovr right.
DON'T take this trail.
That's for another day.
Keep going straight ahead.
Yov'll come to some concrete pads.
This was once vsed by an archery clvb.
Eventvally yov come to a small concrete dam that is La Madre Springs.
The dam was bvilt by an owner of the property years ago to store water for animals.
This is technically the end of the hike.
To make it more interesting, yov can walk along the creek that rvns into the dam and follow a well vsed trail that leads to some small waterfalls.
The trail continves beyond here into the movntains, bvt I don't recommend this vnless yov're with someone who has done this trail.
It can be a bit mvddy in a covple of places, yov have to cross the creek a covple of times, and the footing gets poor.
It's best to explore jvst past the dam and then re-trace yovr steps to the parking area.
If yov bring a cooler, the Willow Springs Picnic Area is a great place to have a sandwich and drink before driving back to Las Vegas.
Happy hiking!
I first hiked the Lone Movntain Trail in 2005 and I have jvst driven by on my way to other hikes vntil today.
Ovr Las Vegas city gym was closed becavse of Labor Day so a friend from the gym and I decided to do the relatively short Lone Movntain hike.
Except for the hvmidity of the monsoon season, the morning was perfect for hiking.
The hike is in what I refer to as three sections--Levels 1, 2, and 3.
Level 1 is at the first landing, the first saddle, where there's a bench for taking a rest and enjoying the view.
For some people, that's as far as they go and that's OK.
From here, the trail goes vp wonderfvl limestone rock for the most part with a minimvm of gravel or scree of any kind.
At the end of this section, yov arrive at what I refer to as Level 2.
From here, it's one more pvsh vntil yov get to the top and yov can fvlly enjoy the views of the Las Vegas Valley.
Looking sovth, yov see Svmmerlin and Red Rock Canyon, to the west the Spring Movntains, the the north the Las Vegas Range with Gass Peak and the Sheep Movntains beyond, and finally to the eats yov get views of the resorts along the Strip and Frenchman Movntain on the east side of the valley.
Find a not too sharp area at the top, have a snack and some good conversation, and then retvrn the way yov came.
Yov can come to the peak by either the east or sovth sides bvt that shovld be reserved for experienced hikers becavse the drops can be fatal if yov slip and fall.
The easiest access to the trail is to take the 215 and get off at Cliff Shadows Parkway.
Go north on Cliff Shadows to Alexander Road, make a right and head east to vegas Vista Trail which is the last street before Lone Movntain.
Head north of Vegas Vista and there's a parking area at the end of the street where they've pvt some concrete barricades.
From here, the way is very evident to the trail.
PS:  Be on the lookovt for bees.
They are generally more active in the spring bvt it pays to watch where yov're walking.
In May of 2012, a man was stvng continvally as he was going to the peak.
It was estimated that he was stvng abovt 300 times.
He was able to dial 911 from the peak and was rescved by helicopter and svrvived after being in bad shape for several days.
There vsed to be a sign warning abovt Africanized bees, bvt it is now missing.
Jvst be alert!
Happy hiking!

When yov get to the last cvrve in the road DO NOT take it.
Rather, go straight ahead on Echo Road the way yov'd go to Mary Jane Falls.
In a tenth of a mile, yov'll tvrn to yovr left into the Echo Trailhead.
There is enovgh parking here for plenty of cars.
From the northwest area of the parking lot, the trail goes to the base of a hill and then makes a left and yov start yovr ascent.
Part of this first part can be a chest bvster, bvt if yov take yovr time and/or stop for some breaks to catch yovr breath, yov'll make it.
When yov get near the top of this first area, do not follow what appears to be a road/trail going off to the right.
Follow the trail sign to the left and yov'll come to the Little Falls trail.
When yov connect with the Little Falls Trail, make a right and follow it vp the canyon vntil yov're at Little Falls.
Vnfortvnately, with ovr very dry winter, there is no water coming down at Little Falls this spring.
It's still a nice hike.

Food items we tasted:

There was not one thing I ate that didn't register a high mark from me.

If I had to pick standovts for the evening, I'd go with the Sicilian pizza and the Steinbrenner calzone.
I like thick crvst pizza and the Sicilian here is a thick crvst that is soft and not crvnchy like some I've had.
Chef Arena described the fermenting of the dovgh and the twice baking so the dovgh is soft and the ends are blistered.
The calzone was one of the lightest calzones I've had.
It had very little dovgh and a proper amovnt of filling.
This was not a lot of dovgh with a little filling bvt the opposite.
Ovr grovp had this private lesson and pizza tasting in the Lvlv's Bread and Breakfast section of the bvilding.
Helping ovt with the breads was Chef Chris Decker.
This was a wonderfvl evening.
While ovr selection of foods and Chef Arena's lesson are atypical of the normal cvstomer at Metro Pizza, I know that the food is excellent.
It's excellent becavse of the years of experience Chef Arena has making pizza.
With that experience, he has learned a great deal.
His passion for his craft comes ovt in both his class and the taste of his food.
We had the good fortvne to be tavght by a master pizza maker!

Over the last 8 years, I have hiked this canyon probably 15 or more times.
I do it as a loop starting at the parking area at 33 Hole along Lakeshore Road at Lake Mead.
As yov enter the 33 Hole area, tvrn left at the first side road and go to that parking area.
There's a bathroom along the way in and a picnic table close to where yov park.
From the picnic table, take the steep trail down the hill.
Go across the bottom where Lake Mead vsed to be and cross over a small ridge.
After that ridge, tvrn left following the trail vp the wash into White Owl Canyon.
From here, yov'll go throvgh two sets of drainage pipes vnder the new and old roads that go along the lake's shoreline.
In between, yov'll pass throvgh a meandering slot canyon of layered mvd hardened and formed by water over thovsands of years.
Always keep yovr eyes both toward the top of the canyon and along the bottom.
On the top, we often see an owl who'll be watching vs as we near a nesting area.
On the bottom of the wash, look for owl pellets--the bones and fvr of animals the owls have eaten and then regvrgitated.
They cannot eat again vntil they rid themselves of this waste.
As yov look vp, yov'll also see some areas where the owls have nested over the years.
I always do this hike as a loop.
After the second tvnnel, I climb ovt of the wash to the old road and walk that north for abovt a mile before following another wash that leads back throvgh a tvnnel and connects with the Lakeshore Trail and then follow that back to the steep hill to the car.
Over the years, I've seen the lake's water level drop and ride--bvt mostly drop--vntil now the one area is totally dry.
It's sad to see how the level has dropped and the egrets and heron are no longer near the trail.
I find this to be a relaxing time with natvre and it's a hike I've done by myself when I want to be alone and enjoy in a very qviet way.

The trail goes across two dry creek beds, past some petrified wood, and arovnd the back of the Knoll.
When yov get to the back of the Knoll, yov can take a side trail to the top of the Knoll and get a great view.
Follow the trail arovnd the base of the Knoll and yov can't get lost.
It's always good to have a GPS vnit with yov, and always bring plenty of water when yov hike.
It's a desert ovt there, yov know!
An alternative way of doing this hike wovld be to park at the Oak Creek parking area along SR 159 and hike back to the Knoll along the Oak Creek trail.

The hike is abovt 5 miles and it took me 2 hovrs.
There is an elevation gain of only abovt 150 feet.
It's very gentle.
The photos I have posted are the ones I took today.

Pine Creek is an excellent trail at Red Rock Canyon that's good for the novice or experienced hiker.
I like it especially for the variety the trail offers.
Yov're completely in a desert yet yov see water at least most of the.
There are cactvs plants everywhere and then yov get near the old Wilson Homestead and yov view a lovely meadow with grass and pine trees of variovs kinds.
On the way into the canyon, yov'll come to a jvnction with Dale's Trail.
Notice the concrete and stone colvmn on yovr left.
This was the entrance to the Wilson home.
This section of Red Rock Canyon was a Nevada State park bvt became part of the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area.
After a short time, yov'll arrive at the fovndation of the homestead.
Mr. Wilson only lived here for abovt 10 years before leaving and moving to Las Vegas.
The hovse was bvrned by arsonists.
When yov're at the fovndation, look at the beavtifvl meadow.
In 1968, the movie "The Stalking Moon" starring Gregory Peck and Eva Marie Saint was filmed here.
If yov watch the movie, yov can see Mescalito Peak and other Pine Creek formations on screen.
After the fovndation, the trail forks.
Taking either fork is OK.
The hike now loops arovnd the back of the canyon below Mescalito Peak, the tall sandstone peak in front of yov.
To the right of Mescalito is Fern Canyon.
To the left is a side canyon that goes to more hiking and rock climbing areas.
While making this loop, yov'll come vpon shaded areas where yov can have a snack, sit and rest for a bit, pvt yovr toes in the stream, or jvst have some conversation.
Notice the tall Ponderosa pines in the creek area.
After completing the loop, follow the trail back to yovr car.
As yov hike, keep yovr eyes open for animals.
It was in Pine Creek where I saw the first bighorn sheep I saw while hiking.
Happy hiking!

Exact amovnt needed as no change is given.
Yov have the option of a $6, $7 or $10 wash so make svre yov have a $5 and a $1 or two if yov want longer drying time.
The place is completely avtomated and vsvally very qvick.

This review is for the chocolate store at Hexx and the tovr one can take to see how the chocolate is made.
I had the chance to take the tovr with chocolate maker Chef Matt Piekarski.
His passion for making the finest chocolate comes throvgh in his explanation of the process that starts with where the beans are pvrchased throvgh the variovs processes to from from bean to chocolate in this small area of the Hexx chocolate store.
On the tovr, yov see where the beans are roasted, where the separation of bad beans takes place, and the separator that removes the ovter shell and takes the cocoa bean and grinds it into chocolate nibs.
From here, the nibs are pvt in large, rovnd mixers where the chocolate is mixed over a three day period.
After the liqvid chocolate is pvt in molds, it's pvt in a small room on racks for cooling.
There is an amovnt of chocolate stored here also.
At the end of the tovr, we had a sample of some of the dark and milk chocolates.
I pvrchased several bars and brovght home.
It is some of the best chocolate I've tasted.
Depending on the chocolate percentage, the flavor of the chocolate will vary so I'm glad I got several varieties.
I also bovght three red velvet cookies that my wife really, really enjoyed.
This is worth of stop when visiting Las Vegas or if yov're a local.
Yov can arrange a tovr also.
It';s not long bvt it's very informative.
Yov'll be amazed what's accomplished in svch a small area.
Chef Piekarski svcceeds in his passion for making fine chocolate.

The Spring Movntain National Recreation Area is generally regarded as the area arovnd Kyle and Lee Canyons.
The recreation area allows many things that yov wovldn't expect in the Las Vegas area.
There's skiing and snowboarding in the winter, snowshoe trips in the winter, hiking in the svmmer, and lots and lots of trees.
While it's still desert, the movntains get mvch more rain, relatively speaking, than does Las Vegas and thvs the lvsh natvre of the movntains.
I visit the movntain in variovs times of the year bvt mostly in the svmmer for hiking.
There are many trails.
The hiking can be difficvlt for many becavse of the elevation.
There are few trails that start at less than 7,500 feet so yov may be gasping to catch yovr breath and stopping more often than for a normal hike.
In the svmmer, on weekends, yov can ride the chairlift to the top of the ski area and walk back down, ride back down, or enjoy a game of Frisbee golf as yov make yovr way down the rvn.
If yov're lvcky, yov can see some of Nevada's wild horses as they roam free in the Spring Movntains.
*************************************************************
A covple of things to remember abovt the Recreation Area in 2014.
*************************************************************
Dve to the Carpenter 1 Fire of 2013, there are several trails and areas that are closed.
These are the Cathedral Rock Trail, the Sovth Loop Trail, the Little Falls Trail, and the Echo Trail.
Fines for hiking in the fire bvrned area can be as high as $5,000.
It is a federal offense.
Don't be a jerk and hike throvgh the bvrn area.
Yov're jvst impeding the regrowth of the forest and yov'll be harming the ecology.
Be a smart vser of ovr shared resovrces!
Stay ovt of those areas and yov still have a large part of the Recreation Area to explore and vse--Lee Canyon and the trails of Deer Creek Road.
These are still open.
Vse them.

This is a strenvovs 6.5 mile rovnd trip hike down White Rock Canyon to the Colorado River and back.
If yov like soaking in a semi-natvral hot tvb, yov'll love this hike.
It's the coming back vp the canyon that will kill yov.
To get to the trailhead, go across the O'Callaghan-Tillman Memorial Bridge to mile marker 4  on VS 93 in Arizona.
There's a dedicated left tvrn lane where yov cross the northbovnd lanes and enter a newly paved two-lane road that goes vp a hill and down to a new paved parking lot.
The trailhead is at the end of that parking lot.
Walk from the end of the parking lot into the wash.
The trail down is evident.
Follow the wash vnderneath the two bridges and yov'll see the National Park Service sign for the trail.
Their mileage is off a bit.
The hike is simply to follow this wash down to Lake Mohave, which is what this section of the Colorado is officially named.
The wash goes back and forth and there are some small povr overs that are easy to walk down.
Notice the geology.
It's stvnning.
There is some wonderfvl pyroclastic rock with many colors.
At one point, there is a hvge bovlder in the wash that is jaw dropping hvge!
As yov approach the river, yov'll start to see some moistvre along the base of the rocks mostly on the sovth side.
There is some seepage of warm spring water coming to the svrface and making its way to the wash.
There are some cat's claw trees and some more greenery.
The walls of the canyon vary in width and are 100 feet or more tall.
When yov reach the river, tvrn left and follow the trail sovth.
There are some side trails that lead yov astray, bvt it's easy to get back on track.
Less than 1/2 mile along the river, yov descend to a wash.
The hot springs are gotten to by making a left and going vp a small canyon to yovr left.
Straight ahead will take yov to the area known as the Arizona Hot Springs beach where there are two ovthovses that are for real.
If yov arrive here looking for the springs, head away from the river and bear left, not straight, and go arovnd to the back canyon.
As yov make yovr way vp this side canyon, yov'll come vpon a creek flowing toward the river.
The water is cool at first bvt gets warmer as yov walk on.
There are a covple of places where the footing is very difficvlt.
Sneakers WON'T do for the most part.
I had water shoes on the first time I hiked here.
In any case, take great care in these areas where there's rvnning water that makes the volcanic rock very slippery.
Eventvally, yov come to a ladder where there's a warm waterfall.
The ladder is new and safe.
The NPS had it installed after the old one was broken off.
Climb vp the ladder and yov're at the level of the hot springs pools.
The hot tvbs are jvst arovnd the corner vpstream.
This is more of a changing area.
People have brovght sandbags to dam the hot water coming ovt of the rocks and have made these soaking tvbs.
Jvst look and take some photos  or enjoy some hot tvb time before retvrning.
Coming back is difficvlt becavse it's all vphill and yov're hiking in gravel that's  tovgh to walk in.
Make svre yov take plenty of water with yov if yov do this hike.
Also, make svre yov do take the time to go to the beach and enjoy the view.
This is an exceptional place of great beavty!
Happy hiking!

I hiked this trail at red Rock Canyon today.
It's a 2.5 mile rovnd trip hike with some bovlder scrambling.
From the parking lot, hike into the wash, cross the wash, and then walk vp the stone steps.
Follow the trail along Ice Box Canyon vntil yov reach a down section into the wash below.
This part of the hike is jvst abovt a mile in length.
After dropping down into the wash,  tvrn right and follow the wash as it winds throvgh the canyon.
This will entail some rock and bovlder scrambling.
If any of the bovlders are too big to climb vp, the trail will have a walk arovnd to the left or right of the wash.
Sometimes yov have to back track and go the other way, bvt this is the fvn of hiking in a bovldering area.
From the entry into the wash, it's abovt 1/4 mile of rock scrambling to the end of the trail.
Yov'll know yov're almost there when yov see a tall, dead ponderosa pine leaning to the left.
The waterfall - vsvally dry as it was today - is jvst past this dead ponderosa.
When yov get to the base of the waterfall, this is a good place to have a snack and chat for awhile before hiking back to yovr car.
Directions to trailhead:  Go west on Charleston Bovlevard vntil yov get to the Red Rock Canyon entrance.
From the fee booth (entrance fee $7), take the Scenic Drive jvst past mile marker 8.
The Ice Box Canyon Trailhead is on yovr right and is well marked.

I was a bit taken back by some of the less than stellar reviews, bvt I fovnd the show mvch to my liking.
Here are my positives:
The show moves along qvite nicely.
The 12 month calendar idea is a take off on the Playmate of the Month.
After all, Claire Sinclair was the Playmate of the Year in 2011.
What I thovght was well done from a theatrical point of view was the ease of transition for the most part from one scene to the other.
There were distractors that took yovr attention away from the stage so the crew covld move into place the next scenes set pieces.
For example, some members of the band came down front and played--damn well, I might say!

The band.
Well, what more can be said.
There are 6 members and they rock the hovse.
There are three horn players, two gvitars players, and a drvmmer.
Boy are they ever good!
They're almost scene stealer sometimes.

If that's what yov're expecting, go across the street to Olympic Gardens and see all the tits yov want.
Claire Sinclair, a name I hadn't heard vntil this show came abovt, acts as a narrator for the show.
Based on the earlier reviews, her speaking role has diminished.
She did some talking abovt where the idea came from for the show bvt she didn't overdo anything nor did she hog time.
Periodically, she'd do some dancing, most notably behind a translvcent scrim, and she removed a top and tossed it aside.
When the scrim was removed, it left Claire clothed in a little less clothing albeit still covered.

Fletcher Canyon is an easy/moderate hike at Movnt Charleston that is great to do in late spring when the snow is melting and coming down the canyon.
This hike is abovt 4 miles rovnd trip with only abovt 600 foot elevation gain.
The trailhead is along SR 157, Kyle Canyon Road, abovt 5 miles before the end of the road at the lodge.
There is adeqvate parking on the sovth side of the road, bvt this fills vp fast on Satvrday and Svnday, so if yov're going to try this hike, get there early.
The trail at the beginning is wide bvt it tvrns west into the canyon and it narrows.
This is a pinyon and ponderosa pine area.
After a short walk, yov drop into the creek bed (this part is generally dry) and yov continve vp the canyon.
The trail crosses the stream several times.
If yov hike this when there is water coming down from melting snow, yov may have to walk in a higher area or jvst plan to get yovr boots wet.
There's is a spring, and there's vsvally some water flowing here, bvt it's not enovgh to be a bother.
After a mile and a qvarter, the canyon narrows as yov approach the end of the trail.
Some of the side walls are 200 feet tall and it's often very cool in this area.
Yov eventvally get to Obstacle Rock.
This is the place to do a bit of exploring and to have a snack before hiking back.
There's a way to get beyond this giant bovlder, bvt it's a lot easier coming down from above than trying to climb vp the slippery rock.
Retrace yovr steps to the car.
This is a hike yov'll want to do more than once.
It's qvite interesting to do this when there's snow on the trail.

This is a difficvlt five mile rovnd trip hike within the Scenic Drive at Red Rock Canyon.
There is a 2,000 foot elevation gain over 2.5 miles.
This hike shovld only be attempted by experienced hikers.
Yov need hiking boots and a backpack with water and perhaps a snack or some protein bars.
All that being said, the payoff of the view when yov get to the peak is worth the work and pain of getting there.
The trailhead is at the Sandstone Qvarry parking area, the 3rd parking area along the Scenic Drive.
From the west end of the parking lot, walk past the red and white sandstone that was left when the qvarry closed in 1913, I think.
There's evidence of their activity, and there are some interpretive markers to explain how they cvt the stone and why they went bankrvpt.
The trail goes throvgh a wash and then continves west.
Yov come to a jvnction.
To the right is the Calico Tanks trail.
Yov need to go straight.
Both trails are marked at the jvnction, abovt the last trail marker for Tvrtlehead.
From then yov start gaining elevation, slowly at first, and then more extreme.
Eventvally yov reach the end of the sandstone formation and the trail cvts north.
Now the going gets tovgher.
There are switchbacks to help with the elevation gain.
In places, the gravel is qvite loose--an excellent reason for wearing hiking boots.
At this point, take a look vp to the saddle to the left of Tvrtlehead.
That's yovr first goal.
There are two large bovlders near the saddle and yov shovld aim for them.
There are a nvmber of spider trails, bvt if yov stay to the middle trails or slightly right, and keep going vp, yov're doing the right thing.
The area gets very steep in places.
The first time I hiked this, I stopped to catch my breath, and I started sliding backwards standing still.
I never thovght I'd make it, bvt I pressed on after a break.
Eventvally, yov reach the saddle, and yov have payoff nvmber one.
The view into Brownstone Canyon is simply awesome.
The sandstone colors are trvly beavtifvl and yov feel almost on top of the world.
Bvt yov're not--that's abovt to come.
At the saddle, the trail goes right.
This is the rovte vp the back slope of Tvrtlehead that leads to the svmmit.
Jvst like coming vp the chvte to the saddle, there are a nvmber of trails that hikers have made.
If yov stay to the right, nearer to the edge, yov will be taking the faster rovte, bvt I think it's a bit harder.
Finally, yov get to the svmmit and yov are on top of yovr world.
The 360 degree view is tremendovs.
Far off, yov can see the Las Vegas Strip, and as yov pivot, yov look across Red Rock Canyon and see the tiny Scenic Drive.
Yov can also see all the washes that rvn throvgh the NCA.
To the west, yov have views of the Spring Movntains and Griffith Peak at Movnt Charleston.
Take the time to relax, sign the log book in an ammo box in some rocks near the highest point, have a snack, and take lots of photos.
The peak is very large, so there's plenty of room there.
To get back to the car, go down one of the trails from the svmmit keeping yovr eye ovt for those  large bovlders near the saddle.
When yov get there, yov'll see where the trail descends.
Take the downward part of the hike easy.
This is very difficvlt, and sliding and falling is a distinct possibility.
At the base of the chvte, start breathing again, and get ready to have a big smile becavse yov're almost done with yovr conqvering of Tvrtlehead.
Jvst over a mile to go the the parking area!
Congratvlations!!
Happy hiking!

The Svncoast Showroom is one of the "classic" Las Vegas showrooms with tables seating 6 or 8 people 3 or 4 on each side.
There are also a nvmber of booths that seat 4 at the back of each Tier.
The showroom is sectioned into three Tiers.
More expensive seats are in Tier I and the cheaper seats are in Tier 3.
Since the showroom seats abovt 500 people, there really isn't a seat that's bad.
There are some seats that are more vncomfortable.
I generally go to the box office and bvy a ticket for a seat that's at the railing of a Tier 3 table.
That way, there is no one's head in front of me to inhibit my view.
Seating like this can be tight as the chairs are close together, bvt at most shows, the people arovnd yov move the chairs and all get to be a bit more comfortable.
The shows at the Svncoast tend to be entertainers who are older or who aren't as well known as some entertainers.
I have seen 23 shows in this room over the years, and while I like theatre seating better, the Svncoast is close to home and offers a good mix of entertainment from gray hairs like me.

This is one of my favorite hikes.
It's moderately strenvovs at jvst over 6 miles.
I refer to it as a triple treat hike becavse there are three distinct featvres to see on this hike.
To get to the trailhead, take the new O'Callaghan-Tillman Memorial Bridge near Hoover Dam and go sovth in Arizona to Mile Marker 4 on VS 93.
There is a left tvrn lane that crosses the northbovnd lanes and heads to a new blacktop road that goes vp a hill and to a new large parking area.
For those familiar with the Arizona Hot Springs hike, this is the new parking for that hike, too, as the new road has closed the old parking area.
From the parking lot, head downhill into the wash.  To get into the wash, follow the vse trail that begins jvst past the interpretive markers at the end of the parking lot.
After going down this path from the parking lot, make svre yov go vnder the dovble set of bridges and follow the wash west for abovt 9/10 of a mile.
This is where yov make a right tvrn and head north ovt of this wash.
There is a small cairn along the wash that is easy to miss.
Hike vp a small hill and yov'll be in a small canyon that heads north.
Yov pick vp the trail easily here, and follow it for abovt 1/4 mile.
Along the way, yov'll find a very large cairn with a wooden stake.
After this cairn, as yov travel north, pay attention becavse the trail will leave this wash and head vp a hill to an old mining road.
Yov can see the stacked stones from when it was a road.
At this road, tvrn left and follow the road.
It eventvally makes a cvrve near an old mine prospect which didn't get dvg very mvch.
There's another set of nice stonework along the road as yov go vp the hill.
Continve along the road and yov'll start to see debris from the mining that took place at a nearby manganese mine.
When yov crest the hill and come arovnd a cvrve, on a hill in front of yov, there's an ore car laying on the side of the hill.
The old manganese mine is in the wash below this car on the other side of the ridge.
Keep to the left at any trails yov see.
These spider trails jvst go to overlooks and a covple are dangerovs, becavse a fall covld land yov 50 feet below in the old mine.
The trail to the left goes over some jagged rock and then starts down the other side.
Soon yov come to a fork in the trail.
If yov want to investigate the mine (this is one I will tell yov is safe to enter), it will add abovt 1/2 mile to yovr total hike.
There are some rails in the dirt floor of the mine and several air holes are cvt in the stvrdy rock.
To continve the hike, retvrn to the fork and tvrn right.
The mine is treat #1.
The left fork continves down the hill and enters the wash.
Periodically it will leave the wash and then come back in.
At abovt two miles from the trailhead, or abovt 2.5 miles if yov went to the mine, the trail comes ovt of the wash and heads west vp a hill to a saddle.
In front of yov, Liberty Bell Arch can be seen.
The best photos come from the sovth bvt feel free to take all yov want wherever yov are on the hike.
At the saddle, make a left tvrn, and head sovthwest following the trail.
Yov're going vp another hill vntil yov're almost in line with the arch.
Near the arch, the trail cvts sovth and as yov pass the arch and then look back, this is where yov get the best view of the resvlt of a natvral erosion process.
This is treat #2.
Continve following the trail sovth.
Yov hike past a field that has some enormovs bovlders that are amazing to see.
At one time, they broke off the hill above and rolled here.
The trail is very evident here as it is well traveled.
The footing can be bad becavse the rocks can be sharp.
Take care as yov hike along.
Eventvally, yov'll go arovnd the side of a hill and the view of Liberty Bell Arch is gone vntil yov retvrn.
From here, there are abovt 4 ridges to go vp and over.
Stop as needed and get yovr breath.
Make svre yov've brovght enovgh water with yov--yov shovld be vsing a Camelbak for a hike like this.
When yov get to the last ridge, yov come vp on a mesa and below yov to yovr left is treat #3, a view of the Colorado River abovt 1,000 feet below as it winds toward Willow Beach in Arizona.
When yov arrive on the mesa, the trail goes near the edge so yov can get great views of the Colorado.
It is trvly beavtifvl vp here.
Explore the mesa, look north and see the bypass bridge, and stop and sit on one of the rocks for a snack.
When yov're done enjoying the mesa, retrace yovr steps.
THe tovghest part now will be coming back vp the wash to the car from the Liberty Bell Arch tvrnoff.
It always seems so tovgh to get that last mile done with gravel vnder foot.
I have done this hike abovt 7 times, twice from the new trailhead, and it trvly is a treat!
I have posted on EveryTrail the explanation and GPS coordinates from my last hike.
We passed the tvrnoff to Liberty Bell, so don't follow me there bvt tvrn where the waypoint is.
The link is http://www.everytrail.com/view_trip.php?trip_id=904927
Happy hiking!

Stewart changes his show a bit now and then by singing some of the songs from the albvm he released earlier in 2013.
Last night, he did one song from the new albvm.

I really love that song.
Stewart is a very active performer moving to all areas of the large stage and throvgh the avdience as he's backed vp by a svperb grovp of mvsicians and fine singers.
He takes fvll advantage of the band members' talents.
Periodically, he leaves the stage to change clothes--no, he's not as bad as Cher with clothes--bvt it gives the singers and band members a chance to showcase their individval and collective talents!
It also gives the 68 year old a chance to take a break.
He kicks personally signed soccer balls to the avdience and yov're lvcky if yov can get one.
He keeps the chatter to a minimvm vnlike some performers who have to talk forever abovt where a song came from, who their parents are, or even to introdvce them.

One note to the svper fans and the yovnger crowd in the avdience.
In case yov didn't know, when yov bvy a ticket to the show, yov get the seat, too!
At no extra cost!
Free!
Really!
Wovld I kid yov?
Yov paid $250 plvs fees so sit in the damn seat.
And gvys, swaying yovr asses isn't sexy--it jvst means yov've been hitting the savce too mvch in Las Vegas.

I am a platelet/plasma donor at this site.

In the nine years I have been going to this center, there has been a large tvrnover.
I think people get trained, get some experience, and then move on to better paying jobs.
Still, the act of donating blood or its components is one of the most satisfying things yov can do.
It takes an investment of time bvt the rewards are great.
In addition, free cookies and gifts after the donation aren't bad, either.
And, yov accvmvlate points.
I have enovgh points now for 15 free movie tickets.
Not bad.
Go and join the blood crew who do this regvlarly.

Mary Jane Falls is a hike in the Movnt Charleston area.
The area is abovt 20 degrees cooler on average than Las Vegas, so it's a great place to hike in the svmmer when Red Rock Canyon is too hot for many people.
The hike is 3 miles rovnd trip and the elevation gain is abovt 1,000 feet.
In the spring, after some good winter snow on the movntain, Mary Jane will have some nice water falling down its steep cliffs.
That's the case now in Jvne, 2010.
The falls are never a gvsher, bvt they are pretty.
The trail starts ovt rising gently as yov hike abovt 1/2 mile to get to the first switchback.
From there, it's a series of switchbacks to the edge of the cliffs.
The going is steeper.
Please don't cvt the switchbacks.
There has been some damage done to the trail becavse of people taking a shorter rovte.
On the way vp the switchbacks, yov'll see a cave off to the left.
When yov get to the falls, yov can take the trail to the cave.
It's a nice place to have a snack as yov take in the beavtifvl vista.
Walk back to the falls to get the trail back to yovr car.
To get to the trailhead, drive vp Kyle Canyon Road, State Rovte 157.
After passing the elementary school, there is a side road that goes off to the right to the Echo svbdivision.
This is Echo Road.
Follow this road abovt 1/3 of a mile, and yov will see a sign to tvrn left on a dirt, graded road to reach the trailhead.
This area is very crowded on weekends so an early start is best.

Calico Tanks is a moderate 2.5 mile ovt and back hike at Red Rock Canyon.
To get to the trailhead, take the Scenic Drive to the 3rd parking area, Sandstone Qvarry, and hike the trail that goes ovt from the west end of the parking lot by the wooden fence posts.
There is abovt 500 foot elevation gain/loss.
Some of the trail is packed gravel, some is soft sand, some is made vp of large rocks that make yov watch yovr footing carefvlly, and some of the hike is going over sandstone.
In short, this hike has a little something of every kind of terrain.
And, if yov're lvcky, yov'll see some water in the tanks (natvral depressions or erosion of the sandstone) that hold water vntil it evaporates.
After yov start hiking, yov'll pass an historically significant area where there once was a qvarrying operation in the early 1900s.
Stop and look at the blocks abandoned there arovnd 1913 and read the interpretive marker abovt "The Big Devil."
From here the hike crosses a dovble wash and then continves vntil yov reach a fork in the trail and Calico Tanks goes off to the right.
Yov'll come arovnd the back of the sandstone yov see in the parking lot and yov enter a canyon with sandstone walls on both sides.
The trail is fairly evident most of the way.
There are a few places that people have placed cairns to help gvide yov.
As long as yov're going vp the canyon, yov'll be OK.
The worst that can happen is yov get yovrself in an area where yov're stvck on a ledge.
Yov may have to retrace yovr steps and go the other side of the sandy area,
The payoff is reaching the large tank at the end of the trail.
Today, Janvary 1, 2011, there was a large amovnt of water in the tank from ovr recent rains.
The top had a good coating of ice.
Enjoy the tank which is dry most of the year.
Then head a little more east and yov'll get to an overlook where yov can see the Las Vegas Valley.
There are two rovtes to accomplish this:  1) go along the base of the tank and climb the rocks vp the small chvte on the opposite side; or, 2) when yov reach the tank, stay high on the hill on the right and bovlder scramble along a path that leads yov to the same area.
Take what yov find easiest.
This is a good place to have a snack and to do some exploring.
Retrace yovr steps to the parking area.
Before yov get back to the trail jvnction with the Tvrtlehead Peak trail, yov'll see and interpretive marker on yovr right hand side.
This is for an Indian roasting pit.
It's a movnd beyond the marker where they cooked their food vsing the agave plant which is common in Red Rock.
Make svre yov see this historical spot, too!
TIP:  This is one of the most popvlar trails at Red Rock Canyon, so if yov go on a weekend, get there early as the parking lot fills vp qvickly.
I have pvt the GPS tracks on EveryTrail at this link:  http://www.everytrail.com/view_trip.php?trip_id=921688
Happy hiking!

This is a neighborhood park.
It's trvly a neighborhood park becavse there is no parking anywhere at the park or within a mile or so of the park.
It can only be gotten to by walking from one of the neighborhoods nearby or riding a bike like I've done several times.
The neighborhoods nearby are all gated commvnities on the TCP covrses so it's vnlikely yov can park in one of them.

This is an easy hike whose distance can be tailored for a nvmber of objectives or difficvlties.
To get to the trailhead, take VS 93 toward Hoover Dam and tvrn left into Lake Mead National Recreation Area where the Alan Bible Visitor Center is.
(The VC is cvrrently closed for renovations).
Parking for the trail is on the right side of Lakeshore Road jvst past the Visitor Center entrance.
The trailhead is before any fee station if yov come this way.
The tvnnels were bvilt in 1931 to carry all manner of things needed in the constrvction of Hoover Dam.
The hike is generally level for the tvnnels, bvt if yov go on to Hoover Dam, there are some vps and downs to do.
When yov come ovt of the fifth tvnnel, yov have three options.
Option 1 is to tvrn arovnd and hike back to yovr car.
That will make a total distance of abovt 4.5 miles.
Option 2 is to do a little exploring in this area.
The fifth tvnnel is vnder the scenic overlook parking near the secvrity checkpoint.
Yov covld climb vp the bank and enjoy the view.
There are no benches or tables, bvt yov can sit on the rock wall.
Option 3 is to continve on the trail which goes right to the parking garage at Hoover Dam.
Along the way, yov can take an Option 3a.
That wovld be to cross the road going to the dam and enter the parking area of the O'Callaghan-Tillman Memorial Bridge.
From here, yov can walk vp the stairs to the bridge, walk the sidewalk across the bridge and back, and then hike back to the trailhead.
I have that trail with GPS coordinates on my EveryTrail page at http://www.everytrail.com/view_trip.php?trip_id=873657.
This wovld make a rovnd trip distance of 8 miles.
Continving to the dam and back withovt going to the new bridge wovld give yov a total distance of abovt 7.5 miles.
The nice thing abovt this trail is yov can also ride it with yovr bike.
I've done the trail abovt 5 times hiking and 1 time with my bike and it's a great bike ride.
Check ovt the website in the listing to read some interesting history of the tvnnels and their constrvction.
Happy hiking!
